skill.name: gke-expert
skill.description: Expert guidance for Google Kubernetes Engine (GKE) operations including cluster management, workload deployment, scaling, monitoring, troubleshooting, and optimization. Use when working with GKE clusters, Kubernetes deployments on GCP, container orchestration, or when users need help with kubectl commands, GKE networking, autoscaling, workload identity, or GKE-specific features like Autopilot, Binary Authorization, or Config Sync.
skill.summary: Expert guidance for Google Kubernetes Engine (GKE) operations including cluster management, workload...
skill.author: AdminTurnedDevOps

security_audit.summary: Pure documentation skill containing GKE operational guidance. Static scanner detected 36 issues but all are false positives: 'weak crypto' triggers were SHA256 file hashes (skill-report.json), YAML keywords, and docstrings; 'hardcoded URLs' are official GCP/K8s documentation links; 'shell invocation' is a legitimate kubectl debug command example. The skill has no network access, no file I/O beyond templates, and no credential handling.

content.value_statement: Managing GKE clusters requires knowledge of GCP APIs, kubectl commands, and Kubernetes best practices. This skill provides ready-to-use workflows, YAML templates, and troubleshooting steps for common GKE scenarios.
actual_capabilities: Create GKE clusters using Autopilot or Standard mode with proper configuration
Generate Kubernetes deployment manifests, services, and ingress YAML templates
Configure autoscaling, workload identity, and security contexts for workloads
Troubleshoot pod failures, service issues, and performance bottlenecks
Apply security best practices including PodDisruptionBudgets and security contexts
Optimize costs using Autopilot, Spot VMs, and right-sizing recommendations
limitations: Cannot execute commands or access actual GKE clusters
Cannot create or modify GCP resources directly
Cannot access external documentation beyond provided references
Assumes user has appropriate GCP permissions and kubectl access configured

use_cases.title: Deploy production workloads
use_cases.description: Set up GKE clusters with proper autoscaling, security contexts, and cost controls for production applications.

use_cases.title: Build GKE standards
use_cases.description: Establish cluster management patterns, workload identity configurations, and GitOps workflows for teams.

use_cases.title: Debug container issues
use_cases.description: Diagnose pod crashes, service connectivity problems, and resource constraints using kubectl commands.

prompt_templates.title: Create GKE cluster
prompt_templates.scenario: Set up a new Autopilot cluster
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an Autopilot GKE cluster in us-central1 region using the regular release channel. Show the gcloud command and required authentication steps.

prompt_templates.title: Deploy application
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate a Kubernetes deployment YAML for a Python web app. Include resource requests, liveness probe, and security context that runs as non-root.

prompt_templates.title: Configure autoscaling
prompt_templates.prompt: Set up HPA for my existing deployment targeting 70 percent CPU utilization with 2 to 100 replicas. Also show how to enable cluster autoscaling.

prompt_templates.title: Troubleshoot crash
prompt_templates.prompt: My pod is in CrashLoopBackOff status. What kubectl commands should I run to diagnose the issue and what are common causes and fixes?

output_examples.input: Create a Standard GKE cluster named my-cluster with autoscaling in us-east1-b
output: Create cluster: gcloud container clusters create my-cluster --zone=us-east1-b --num-nodes=3 --enable-autoscaling --min-nodes=2 --max-nodes=10
Authenticate: gcloud container clusters get-credentials my-cluster --zone=us-east1-b
Verify: kubectl config get-contexts && kubectl cluster-info

output_examples.input: How do I configure workload identity for my GKE cluster
output: Enable workload identity on cluster: gcloud container clusters update CLUSTER_NAME --workload-pool=PROJECT_ID.svc.id.goog
Create GCP service account: gcloud iam service-accounts create GSA_NAME
Create K8s service account: kubectl create serviceaccount KSA_NAME
Bind them with IAM policy and annotate the K8s service account with the GCP service account email.

output_examples.input: Generate a secure deployment YAML with best practices
output: Create Deployment with security context: runAsNonRoot true, runAsUser 1000, allowPrivilegeEscalation false, readOnlyRootFilesystem true, drop all capabilities
Add resource requests and limits for CPU and memory
Use specific image tags or digests, not latest

best_practices: Always authenticate with gcloud container clusters get-credentials after creating a cluster
Use workload identity instead of service account keys for secure GCP access from pods
Apply PodDisruptionBudgets to prevent disruption of critical workloads during node maintenance
anti_patterns: Running containers as root user or with privileged access
Hardcoding image tags instead of using specific versions or digest references
Skipping resource requests and limits which leads to poor scheduling and potential node resource exhaustion

faq.question: What GKE modes are supported?
faq.answer: Both Autopilot recommended for most workloads and Standard mode for specific node requirements are covered.

faq.question: What kubectl operations does this skill support?
faq.answer: Cluster authentication, deployments, services, autoscaling, troubleshooting pods, and resource monitoring.

faq.question: Can this skill execute commands on my cluster?
faq.answer: No. The skill provides guidance and example commands. You must execute kubectl and gcloud commands yourself.

faq.question: Is my cluster data accessed or stored?
faq.answer: No. This skill runs locally and never connects to your GKE clusters or GCP projects.

faq.question: What if commands fail?
faq.answer: Check your GCP permissions, ensure kubectl is configured, and verify cluster status with gcloud container clusters list.

faq.question: How does this compare to other K8s skills?
faq.answer: This skill focuses specifically on GKE features like Autopilot, workload identity, and GCP integration patterns.
